the only way I like pineapple on pizza is layered: Dough Light sauce Cheese(good amount) Pepperoni or bacon Pineapple (squeeze out excess juice, and it HAS to be the last topping put on. Even better if you can put the pizza in and let the cheese melt before you put the pineapple on to finish it)  This way the fat in the cheese and pepperoni form a barrier and fry out any extra pineapple juice. You end up with a crispy crust. You have to have the meat in place, the cheese won't melt fast enough to keep the pineapple from making the crust soggy.

So I've got a very specific issue with chicken on pizza. A pizza doesn't spend long enough in the oven for chicken to cook from raw. This means that the chicken needs to be pre-cooked before it goes in the oven, which means it's dry and overcooked by the time it's ready to eat. Also, chicken is bland and doesn't really go with cheese anyway.  Also, pineapple just tastes like shit anyway..

The issue I have with pineapple on pizza is that most places use the wet stuff right out of a can. It just soaks the pizza and ruins the cooking process, screws up the cheese and everything. I've had like, _ONE_ good pineapple pizza from a place that used dried pineapple slices that soaked up the oils of the pizza itself, but sadly most places don't do that.

blah blah blah, Pineapple on pizza, anchovies on pizza. It's all pretty irrelevant when you realize that Pizza is just a Salad.  Hear me out; What is a salad? It's a vegetable base (Lettuce, kale, spinach etc) with bits of meat, shredded cheese and some kind of sauce or dressing. What's a pizza?  It's a vegetable base (wheat), with bits of meat (Ham, pepperoni, etc), and a sauce.   Ergo, pizza is a salad.   Thank you for coming to my TED Talk, I will not be taking questions.

Soâ€¦8 slices in 8 minutes... So not counting his talking from the point he ordered the second one to when he got it is around 2 to 4 minutes itâ€™s, so in this calculation Iâ€™ll do the maximum. That means for 1 pizza 8 slices is 8 minutes , and 4 double slices is 4 minutes if we asume it takes one minute for one to eat a double slice. Not doing triple cuz thatâ€™s harder to calculate. So to eat and order another pizza, it takes about 8 minutes, but if one starts to get full, it will take longer. So all that extra time will be evaluated by saying 10 minutes to eat and receive a new pizza. Now, 2 hours is 120 minutes divided by 10 minutes is 12. So one can get 12 batches of 8 sliced pizza, which is 96 total slices maximum for our values. Now, that divided by 2 is 48, so if it took 20 minutes, or double the time, it would still be higher than the original goal. Oh, and also great video!

My favourite pizza toppings are pineapple and olives with ranch dressing as the base. It may sound weird, but it provides the perfect combination of sweetness, saltiness, and creaminess in every bite. Plus I don't eat pork so I have to find alternatives to pepperoni and other pork-made pizza toppings whenever I eat pizza which can be pretty tricky sometimes, depending on where I go. Some people, especially old-school Italians in New York if I can put it that way look at me genuinely horrified when I bring this up to them and request alternative pizza toppings such as these but I always tell them hey, don't knock it til u try it brother (que Hulk Hogan).

Pineapple has no business being anywhere NEAR a pizza. On a different note, my family once went to a local pizza parlor and my dad ordered a large pepperoni pizza for my mom, brother, sister, myself and himself. My older brother was a human vacuum cleaner when he was in high school. He sat down that day, and proceeded to eat half of the pizza by himself. Leaving the other 4 of us to eat the remaining half. My younger sister had one final piece of pizza sitting on her plate once the rest of the pizza was gone. My brother (ever the opportunist) asked her if she was going to eat that piece of pizza. My sister said no, so he inhaled it. As he swallowed the last bite, he began to stick each of his fingers in his mouth one by one to make sure he got every morsel. Suddenly, a confused look came over his face. He said to my sister, "Um,...didn't I see you pouring salt all over a pice of pizza a little while ago? What happened to that piece?" She said, "You just ate it." His reply was that it didn't taste like salt. She said, "That's because I licked the salt off." My brother slowed WAYYYYY down, and made himself ask more questions after that as we all had a great laugh.

I have never noticed stretching extend my reach... I am like the least flexible person ever. But i spent like 2 years stretching regularly with exercise. When I started i couldn't touch my toes. When i finished i still couldnt touch my toes. I only ever noticed that peforning the stretches got mildly less painful. The actual limit of my stretching never changed.  I don't think it's stretching that makes you flexible, vut regularly doing things that require you to be flexible. Like a gymnast is flexible because she tries to be, not because she stretches every day. That's what i think.   And then your body formation is probably the most important thing. For instance, i cannot touch my toes, but i used to work with a guy who was born with hypermobility. Hypermobility for some reason allows some people to be born hella flexible. My former colleague could take his foot, twist it 360 degrees, and then twist an even further about 300 degrees (so we're talking about 660 degrees of turns here) and it didn't bother him... He would then let go of his foot and it would whip back around into place :/ made a horrible wet noise too with his flesh.  All this to say that if you wanna get flexible for the karma sutra, then i dont think stretching while you're out and about is going to make ready for that. I think you just need to be attempting the positions

The gamer in me is seeing optimization with how long it takes to make each pizza. Faster pizzas give more time toward eating. If you are concerned about flavor fatigue, starting with a pizza that takes longer to cook will save time on the onset. This also ignores any advantage there might be with starting with a smaller pizza first, since there is a major uptick in the time it takes to finish each pizza. And also assumes each pizza will take the same time to cook, regardless of what's going on in the kitchen.   1st pizza done at 1:51:17. 8 minutes 43 seconds to finish.  2nd pizza ready at 1:46:20. 4 minutes 57 seconds after 1st pizza was done.  2nd pizza done at 1:38:16. 8 minutes 4 seconds to finish.  3rd pizza ready at 1:33:04. 5 minutes 12 seconds after 2nd pizza was done.  3rd pizza done at 1:23:33. 9 minutes 31 to finish.  4th pizza ready at 1:19:40. 3 minutes 53 seconds after 3rd pizza was done. It was quick.  4th pizza done at 1:06:55. 12 minutes 45 seconds to finish.  5th pizza ready at 1:00:50. 6 minutes 5 seconds after 4th pizza was done.  5th pizza done at 0:35:20. 25 minutes 30 seconds to finish.  6th pizza ready at 0:27:03. 8 minutes 17 seconds after 5th pizza was done.  6th pizza finished at 0:02:19. 24 minutes 44 seconds to finish.   Since the 1st and 2nd pizzas were the same, we can assume it takes the same amount of time to cook the 1st pizza as the 2nd pizza. Now we can swap the 1st pizza with the 6th pizza, since that one took the longest to finish. We'll replace the time to cook the 6th pizza with the time to cook the 2nd. That saves 3 minutes 20 seconds. There was 2 minutes 19 seconds remaining at the end, with the saved time there's just enough left to cook another pizza and maybe finish an extra slice.   Gaming.

Look, I come from generations of pureblood neapolitans (I sounded like a goddamn Slytherin right there but you get the point), all that matters to me is that the pizza is good and tasty. Anchovies pack a surprising umami bomb that grows on you, and pineapple and ham- without the acidity of the tomato, makes for a lovely sweet and sour taste that reminds you of asian cuisine. Pizza at its core needs to be a cheap, tasty meal rather than a war on toppings.  A personal metric of quality is if the pizza sits well with you. If you have to drink gallons of water as you're digesting it or feel unhappily bloated, it either means the dough was leavened incorrectly by adding too much yeast, or that you ate 5 or more pies in one sitting ;)))

when it comes to pineapple ON pizza it's a hard no for me, when you bake the pineapple the enzymes in the pineapple are broken down. and you want those enzymes to break down the grease from (american styled) pizzas. that being said, I will always be an advocate for pineapple WITH (american) pizza, as a side dish! the sweetness of the pineapple really compliments the saltiness of the cheese and the thick breading (assuming you dont get thin crust). and like I said before, the enzymes in the pineapple will help with breaking down the grease from (american style) pizzas so you dont feel as bloated and icky from it!  tl;dr = pineapple on pizza is bad, pineapple as a side dish to pizza is good!

Fresh pineapple is the only way to go. Also precooking it is optimal so that the texture doesn't clash too much when you throw it on the pizza. Personally, the only pizza I actually enjoy pineapple on from a commercial standpoint (where they use the pineapple drenched in corn syrup) is BBQ chicken pizza. It goes REALLY well on that pie since it's already a great mix of sweet and savory. But pineapple on red sauce is just not it. Final conclusion, pineapple is great on pizza, but there's a time and place for it, it doesn't belong on every pizza in my humble opinion.

But he had a large family who regularly stole his pizza, so he started adding toppings that no one would touch, which happened to be anchovies and pineapple. I don't like "traditional' Hawaiian pizza, pizza the chunks of pineapple are waaaaay too big, often way too thick, so nahhh.. But i've actually found a little hack I can do at home. There's some 'decent', not good but half-good frozen Hawaiian pizzas, and while the pizza is still frozen I take it out of the box, remove the pineapple, and finely, finely dice the pineapple into little tiny pieces. Then, i'll evenly distribute them over the ham pizza and bingo! Just phenomenal, I love it! But I won't eat a Hawaiian with big chunks, or I would never order it at a good pizza place. Too many better choice in my opinion

I love pineapple on my pizza. The best pizza we ever had was at a Pizza Inn back in the 1980's. My wife and I usually got a thin crust with beef, mushrooms, onions, and half olives. Our pizza came out in like 4 minutes instead of the normal 20. It had jalapenos on the whole thing and looked and smelled amazing. Within 5 minutes we were fighting over the last slice! While we were fighting our waitress came over to our table and declared, "Oh no! You just ate so-and-so's pizza!" I say so-and-so because it was a female Vietnamese's employees lunch we had just eaten and I cannot remember her name. She came over to our table and we explained how much we loved the pizza. We asked her what she did to make it so good. She told us she did several things to enhance the pizza.The only one I remember is that she kneaded some vinegar from the jalapeno jar into the dough. What a great pizza!

Going back 15 years I found an amazing Chinese restaurant that did all you can eat but not as a buffet, it was eat an entire dish and you could order 2 at a time but you couldn't order more until you finished, to be honest I only wanted a small amount of each food but I couldn't do that so ended up eating 6 plates of food, yet by halfway through dish 2 I was feeling sick. the look I got from the staff felt like they saw me as greedy! Looking back I think I forgot to tip them.
I used to get this coupon that they would never take back if i tipped decently. the coupon was for papa johns and it was buy one get one pizza of any size or number of ingredients for free. soo I have tried a ridiculous amount of pizzas. regarding pineapple. here's the recipe I that's my favorite that blends the pineapple flavor into the pizza without it standing out.   Marzano tomato sauce, cheeses of your choice, pepperoni, pineapple, onion, and jalepeno pizza. the onions and jalepeno's counter the pineapple to a point that the flavors blend unbelievably well. I think think its a combo from the cheese fat along with the stronger flavor that the ingredients have that then work to counter each other. give it a try and let me know what you think. if you dont like things hot, remove the jalepeno seeds and that reduces the heat.

I just want you guys to gain a perspective real quick about how much this mans just ate.   The average Male that's 5"8" eats about 2000-2500 a day to maintain a weight of 140LBS.  The average pizza slice for a 14 inch pizza is about 200-250 Calories (No Toppings)  This man ate 48 slices of pizza. So let's do some really terrifying math now. If we take the average pizza slice for just cheese being about 225 Just to be in that middle area and multiply it by 48, we get a whopping 10,800 Calories.   Now keep in mind, he had 3 other Pizza Pie's containing Toppings like Chicken, Onions, Pineapple. Assuming that the chicken pizza contains roughly 6Oz of chicken, that's another 400calories extra...  You get the point, this guys ate probably more than 11K calories in one sitting, I didn't even include the Milkshake which typically carry 600-1K calories depending on flavor type, extra ingredients like cookies, whip cream, etc.   Give this man the subs, he deserves your sub, because that's a feat not many can accomplish and he did it for CONTENT  *Edit* Yes I know this guys channel is all about eating a metric F*** ton of food. Which is still insane. I can't do what he does. The most I've eaten like once in a long time ago was like 4K and that was for muscle gain.

No I'm not kidding!) and invariably the toppings are sparce. And crazily they're expensive! Pineapple on pizza is an abomination
everyone has a right to an opinion, and that right must always be respected. that being said, hawaiian pizza does not make sense on very many levels. pineapple is incredibly sweet, and handily overpowers the tomato sauce, which is normally a source of delicate, subtle sweetness in pizza, while lacking the acidic, tart and deep red flavors that tomatoes have when cooked at high temperatures. in terms of texture, pineapple has a full-bodied, juicy and fruity consistency which stands at extreme odds with the toothsome, crispy texture of good pizza. Not only does the pineapple not serve to enhance the texture of the pizza like a crispy basil or smooth sauce, it actively works against it.  ham, as opposed to a more typical pepperoni, lacks all the crispy texture and delicious fat of pepperoni. on top of that, it presents a hideous texture and consistency of luncheon meat, which further detracts from the texture of quality pizza. if that weren't enough, it provides yet more unwarranted sweetness on top of the pineapple. the flavor of the ham, which is usually of poor quality, is astringent and easily overpowers delicate flavors of mozzarella, tomato sauce, and the pizza dough.  Both the ham and the pineapple introduce unwanted moisture to the pizza, which further acts to soak the crust and deprive it of its crispy exterior, not to mention the negative impact that has on the eating experience.  in summary, hawaiian pizza takes the formula of a good pizza, and flattens the flavor range on both the high and low ends, while detracting from its texture, all with an overbearing sweetness, and bastardizing two proud and beautiful cultures simultaneously.  thank you

I am SO SURPRISED that this restaurant has pineapple pizza. I am 100% convinced that like 99% of people that are so extreme on their opinion about it, saying it's some crime against food, are just repeating what Gordon said. Gordon said he absolutely HATES pineapple pizza, so I actually believe most people just accept his word as gospel instead of accepting that it's very subjective because Gordon hated on it as something objectively bad. So why does one of his restraurants offer it? xD Maybe he changed his mind, or maybe he was just overly dramatic for the views and doesn't actually mind it that much. Or it's a pure business decision, because even though he thinks it doesn't go well with pizza, he still knows that there are enough people that will order it.  Oh and my take on it, I LOVE it. I'd rather eat a pizza made out of old rubber tires than endure the sweet and savory betrayal of a pineapple slice on my beloved pie. Pineapple doesn't belong on pizza; it belongs in a blender, blended into a tropical smoothie far, far away from my pepperoni!  If I wanted a fruity dessert, I'd order one! Pizza should be savoury, cheesy, and delicious, not some confused culinary experiment. Pineapple on pizza is like trying to make a shoe out of a watermelon â€“ completely absurd and just plain wrong!  So, to all you pineapple pizza lovers out there, you can keep your fruit salad concoction, and I'll stick to the real pizza that doesn't make me question the very fabric of human taste buds.

the gordon clip at the end made it hahaha also about if pineapple should be on pizza that argument never makes much sense to me because pizza is generally a prepared dish that adapts many different food groups on purpose its the point so essentially what im getting at here is pizza=variety in the same way that when im at a buffet i dont expect my options to be salad and nothing else because thats not the point or if i order a assortment dish i expect variety on it so when i go to a pizza place i expect the same not just cheese pizza and thats all i get people have different taste and thats good but dont argue the (->should<- pineapple be put on pizza) because to be that seems dumb instead say i dont like pineapple on my pizza so i dont order it lol

pineapple on pizza is nice if the pineapple is added on after the pizza has been cooked. if you add it after, the acidity cuts through the saltiness of meat toppings while still being fresh. and doesnt interfere with other toppings. if you cook the pineapple onto the pizza, it gets more acidic, and the pineapple melts into the tomato sauce and turns it from alkaline into acidic. from a pH 8 down to a 6-ish.

pineapple on pizza all day
There are 2 keys do doing pineapple right on a pizza.  1. Grill or Sautee the pineapple first with a bit of butter before putting it on the pizza.  You want ultimate caramelization so the pineapple is golden or a little chard when it comes out of the oven.  2.  You want to offset the sweetness with just a touch of heat.  I recommend adding fresh jalapenos, if those are too hot, I recommend deveining and deseeding the jalapenos before dicing them and adding them to the pizza instead of bell pepper.  If you deseed/devein it right, there should only be just enough heat on the pepper flesh to make your tongue tingle for a few minutes while providing 2-3 times as much flavor as a bell pepper.

Pineapple on pizza is a really tricky thing for me.  I was born and raised on NY style pizza in the North Eastern USA, but have lived in Hawaii for the later half of my life.  So the first part makes getting pizza that think tastes good really hard.  Because I have l have lived in Hawaii as long as I have and know what a fresh pineapple taste like in addition to a fresh premium pineapple, eating a subpar pizza with canned pineapple on it is really really hard.  That being said, if the place shreds the pineapple instead of placing chunks or quarter rings or even whole rings, that helps out a lot.  The other condition, the Canadian Bacon or ham have to be salty enough to pull their own weight against the sweet pineapple.

Congratulations!!!!!!   I have trouble with two Deep Dish Chicago slices, let alone all the pizza you had.   To be clear because lots of people dont know the difference between Deep Dish and "Chicago Deep Dish,"   Deep Dish has a really thick bread like crust,  "Chicago Deep Dish" has a corn based crust, its a little bit thicker than thin crust, the whole rest of the pizza, and they are huge, is nothing but toppings and cheese, usually very high quality, and it has marinara sauce on the top and center of it, it makes it look like a giant red bullseye.    Each slice because of all the toppings and cheese is about equal too a whole medium sized pizza give or take a slice.

anything on top of a pizza works as long as you make it taste right . . .  hawaiian pizza is good if it's made right . . white oyster sauce, canadian bacon (the canuks hate it when we call it that), real bacon bits and fresh cut grilled pineapple . . . . i've had a buffalo mac & cheese pizza that was fuck'n unreal and i certain it was gonna be shite . . . same with a full on taco salad pizza thought no way too busy, amazing . . . thin crust, bean base, meat, lettuce, white onion, cheddar cheese, tomato and a shot of home made guac & sour cream on each slice.   the fish pizza i had was similar to gordons' but with a completely different base. . .another oyster white sauce, white fish, basil & purple onion and it was on a thicker crust with a garlic salt & parm brushed around the crust. . . . oh and an amazing side note, my wife is a celiac so i get to MAKE all those pizzas on the regular :) if you can get a gluten free crust to look, work and taste like regular pizza crust then you win life :) it only took me about 8 yrs to figure it out hehe

Well, since you asked.  I've never understood the vitriol some people have for pineapple on pizza. One of my good friends is religiously against it, though she can't explain why other than to say it's "disgusting" and "fruit shouldn't be on pizza." She doesn't like when I point out that tomatoes and peppers are fruits. As for myself, I'm a huge fan for balancing and contrasting flavours. Salty pork is so good when paired with sweet and acidic fruits, so it's absolutely one of my favourite combinations. I like to put pickled jalapenos on as well so that there's some sour and heat to go with it.

Lol. As a cook myself, I would have given you every spicy option if you didn't specify) just to stop you from making me work more. But it would be cool to serve you... on a dead day But ey, If you want a tip for getting over the "spicy" food... get some very mild hot sauce, and take a shot of it every day. It will suck but you will build some tolerance. When you get used to that level of spice, get a sauce that is a bit spicier. Don't skimp either, get good quality sauces, not just the ones that burn you for no reason. Keep doing that, and it won't bother you as much. After a while (IMO) you'll might find that "hot" stuff actually goes down quicker! It does for me, but I'm no champion eater... Unless its spicy ass food. Haha

HeyğŸ˜€ I starting watching in early August.  It's impressive you can eat so much.  I've only seen you not finish once (that pancake challenge).  I had a Donald Duck storybook when I was 4yrs old.  In the story, Donald's favorite pizza was Hawaiian (ham, pineapple & anchovies).  Everyone else in the Duck family thought it was disgusting. I was a fussy eater as a kid, but the idea of pineapple on a pizza was something I remember actually wanting to try.  I never did have an opportunity to try pineapple on a pizza until I met my current girlfriend 4 years ago.  She and her 14 yr old daughter will only eat Dominos' flat crust pizza with feta, green olives and pineapple. Back in 2011, I had another girlfriend who always watched Two & A Half Men.  In one episode, Charlie remarked "Y'know who puts pineapple on a pizza?  Homosexuals."  I always thought that joke was below-the -belt.  It was a mean, broad generalized statement.  You shouldn't make fun of people for what they like. I also watch a video game review channel called Rerez.  The two guys who do the voice-overs once argued over pineapple on a pizza.  One liked it, one didn't.  All that being said; I like pineapple on pizza.  Definitely not a traditional topping, but I love going to Pizza Hut and getting a large with just pineapple and bacon.  It's sweet meets salty.  I'll only get it for myself though.  If buying for a group, the safest bet is a couple of Meat Lovers.   I've heard you mention you're from Northern England a few times.  Black Sabbath fan?  Iron Maiden fan?  Judas Priest fan?  Ever been to Birmingham?  Ever met any of them?

Pineapple on pizza is just a topping ingredient. To complain about it "not being traditional" or "cursed" has clearly not ever seen one with brussel sprouts on it. Pineapple works because it's a little bit of sweet, but not too much of it. You wouldn't get the same result with other similar ingredients, like apple or grapes. It's just like how you can use cauliflower on pizza, but broccoli isn't as good of an ingredient for pizza. It's just somehow good for pizza specifically.

So sometime around 2009 a representative from Domino's created a Facebook page called "Pineapple does NOT belong on pizza!!!" and, for the very first time, spurred an online polarized debate club. This drove sales at the company as it was free advertising every time someone got on the page and said "Well Domino's or Little Caesars or x pizza company actually does it right, so I think it does belong on pizza." People kept engaging with it and it plunged us, and the entire internet, into an era of polarized instability. You have to be for, or against, *something.* The online algorithms dictated it for years.   Domino's stock price jumped from 5.88 in early 2009 to over 14 dollars in late 2010. Their strategy worked flawlessly.

Arguably, there is no right nor wrong for pizza toppings, or indeed any other foods. Go with what you like and don't let anyone else tell you otherwise. Unless you try new things, you won't enjoy all the world has to offer.   Anchovies as an example are great unsalted and salted they are used in all sorts of things you wouldn't think of, Lea and Perrins Worcestershire Sauce is well known as a flavour enhancer. What about pickled herring (roll mops), they sound bad, but taste really good on a blini as an appetiser.  Korean Kimchi (pickled cabbage), also sounds bad, but wait till you have tried it and you will probably change your mind.  Pineapple works well in sweet and sour recipes, so why not on a pizza (as not as its not frazzled to a dry lump)  Just because one person doesn't like something, doesn't mean that it shouldn't be offered to others that can appreciate that taste.  I will draw the line at courgettes though :-)
